column3: Kathmandu Pokhara Sightseeing Tour offers the perfect combination of Kathmandu’s cultural heritage sites and the natural serenity.&lt
Delightful scenic lakeside town with the spectacular backdrop of Mt. Machhapuchhre.&lt
Holy Gupteshwor cave,  historical Museum, magical sceneries from Sarangkot Hill and World Peace Pagoda.&lt
Enjoy the Jungle Safari, canyoning, bird watching , elephant safari, and wilderness at Chitwan National Park.&lt

column5: s:3222:""In a tour, the vehicle transfers all the heavy items and equipments. But the Personal belongings of the clients which are required at any moment like money, water bottle, camera, suns cream and toilet paper etc. should be carried by yourself. It’s therefore, advisable that you pack the personal belongings into your daypack.

column3: Duffel or Rucksack bag or suitcase.&lt
Warm wool or synthetic hat that covers your ears (only if you are traveling in the cold season i.e January, February and December)&lt
Goggles or sunglasses for sunbeam, dust and wind.&lt
A neck warmer is another piece of gear for extra warmth if you feel you will need it and is for cold season i.e January, February and December.(optional)&lt
1 pair warm gloves (This is required if you are traveling in cold season i.e January, February and December).&lt
Waterproof (preferably breathable fabric) shell jacket (preferable if you are traveling in rainy season from June to September.)&lt
1 pair cotton pants (loose jeans/khakis), 1 pair shorts.&lt
2 pairs lightweight long underwear/thermals (if you are traveling in winter January, February and December).&lt
2 pairs of liner socks, synthetic or Capilene.&lt
1 pair light camping shoes or sneakers.&lt

column1: Please note our guide will also carry the first aid kit bag during the trek. However, we still recommend you to bring your personal first aid kit as well.

column3: Extra Strength Excedrin for altitude related headaches.&lt
Ibuprofen for general aches and pains.&lt
Immodium or Pepto Bismol capsules for upset stomach or diarrhea.&lt

1 small personal sized first-aid kit with blister treatments such as mole skin, band-aids, some waterproof tape, anti-infection ointments, etc. Your guides will have more extensive medical gear, but you should have the basics for general use.&lt
Passport and extra passport photos (4 copies).&lt
Airline ticket (Please make a copy and leave on at our office in Kathmandu just in case if you need to change the date of your).&lt
Durable wallet/pouch for travel documents, money &amp

Lip balm. At least SPF 20, 2 sticks. A string taped to the stick is helpful, to hang around your neck and some are now being sold with a cord already attached. Handy as it avoids you from having to stop and look for it.&lt
Toiletry kit. Be sure to include hand wipes, and liquid hand sanitizer&lt

column53: s:170:""Our airport representative will be receiving you at Tribhuvan International airport. You will be then transferred to your respective hotel in our private tourist vehicle.""
column55: s:1122:""This includes a final briefing and preparations for the trip. For the meeting, please make sure you bring your passport, two copies of passport-size photos, and a readable copy of your travel insurance policy. After the pre-trip meeting, your sightseeing trip will start. You will have a private vehicle and a professional tour guide at your disposal.

column1: Bhaktapur Durbar Square is a collection of pagoda and shikhara – style temples grouped around a fifty-five-window palace of brick and wood. The attraction of the Bhaktapur Durbar Square is the Lion gate, the Golden gate, the Palace of fifty-five windows, art galleries, and the statue of King Bhupatindra Malla.

The temple is situated on a ridge overlooking the Kathmandu valley, about 12 km east of the city. Dedicated to the Hindu God Vishnu, it is one of the finest and oldest specimens of pagoda architecture built in 323 AD by King Haridatta Verma. The temple is richly decorated with sculptures and carvings, and its position above the Kathmandu valley affords a beautiful view of the surrounding countryside.""
Founded in the 7th century, Bungamati is home to one of the most important God of the Kathmandu Valley, Matsyendranath or the God of Rain &amp
column2: Compassion. Worshipped equally by Hindus and Buddhists, the god is accredited by local people with the introduction of rice plantations in the valley. The rich heritage and relatively unchanging lifestyle of the Newar people are clear to see both in Bungamati and in the nearby village of Khokana, which we also visit.

column1: Patan Durbar Square is an enchanting combination of palace buildings, artistic courtyards and graceful pagoda temples. The former royal palace complex is the center of Patan’s religious and social life, and houses a museum containing an array of bronze statues and religious objects. One remarkable monument here is a 17th-century temple dedicated to the Hindu god Krishna, built entirely of stone.
We will then have an hour of scenic drive to Nagarkot, famous for its vantage point of mountains and sunrise and sunset.""
column3: s:253:""After an early breakfast we head to Pokhara on a tourist vehicle which is about six to seven hours drive. The notorious Prithvi Highway, which winds through 206 km of classic Middle Hills countryside, should be seen as more than just a painful bus ride.""
column5: s:1424:""Your sightseeing trip will start after breakfast. We provide a private vehicle and a professional tour guide. The places we visit are as below:

column1: Lies in the center of religious old bazaar. It is dedicated to Goddess Bhagwati, yet another manifestation of Shakti. The park grounds offer a fine picnic and relaxing area.

The two lakes lie in the north-east of the Pokhara valley at a distance of 13kms from the main city of Pokhara. These lakes are located at the foothill of Begnas, mountain and are separated by the Pachabiya hill.

Locally known as Patale Chhango, these amazing waterfalls lie in the southern flank of the Pokhara. Here  the stream flowing from Phewa lake collapses and surges down the rock into a deep gorge, leaping through several potholes. This is hugely popular with tourists and locals alike.

The revered Gupteswar Cave is situated 2 kms from Pokhara airport. The entrance is right across from Davis Falls and the cave is almost 3 kms long. It has some big hall-sized rooms and some passages where you have to crawl on all four. This cave holds special value to Hindus since a phallic symbol of Lord Shiva is preserved here in the condition it was discovered.
Lies at the north of the Pokhara valley. It is a large limestone cave which is one of the few stalagmites stalactite caves found in Nepal.""

During the tour, we will visit two different museums: one museum displays the lifestyles and history of the Gurungs, Thakalis and Tharu, while the other, Gurkha Memorial Museum, is dedicated to the famous Gurkha Warriors who earned their name in many fierce battles fought during the World Wars and numerous operations around the world since 1815. The soldiers of the Gurkha regiment won 13 Victoria Cross medals awarded for exceptional bravery shown in the field.

Situated at an altitude of 800m above sea level, Phewa is the second largest lake in the kingdom.  The Barahi Island Temple, which lies in the middle of the lake, is dedicated to the Goddess Barahi. This two-storied pagoda temple is dedicated to the female force Shakti. The reflection of Mt. Machhapuchhare and Annapurna can be seen in its serene water. Thick forest lies on the adjoining southern slopes of the lake.
Carved by Seti-Gandaki, the gorge is one of the natural wonders of Pokhara. K.I. Singh bridge at Bagar, Mahendrapool &amp
column2: Prithivi highway Bridge near bus park, provides a perfect view of the river’s dreadful rush and the deep gorge made by the turbulent flow of white water.

column1: The Tibetan village Tashiling in the south and the Tashi Palkhiel village in the north of Pokhara are renowned for the production and trade of woolen carpets and other handicrafts. The original Tibetan settlers in this region migrated to Nepal in the ‘50s.""
column3: s:809:""Wake up early to catch the sunrise from Sarangkot Hill.

column1: A drive of 45 minutes with 25 minutes hike brings us to the view point of Sarangkot. It is the best spot in Pokhara to view the Himalayas. Get mesmerized with the magical sight of the golden sun rising over white spires of the Annapurna range, Dhaulagiri and Machhapucchre (Fishtail Peak), including views of the beautiful the Pokhara Valley and Phewa Lake. It takes about 15-minute walk down and 45 minutes’ drive to the hotel in Pokhara. Return to hotel for breakfast.

Drive to Chitwan National Park afterward. Upon reaching Chitwan National Park resort, you would be briefed by our Guest Relations Officer. After the lunch you would be going for Village tour. Meanwhile the dinner would be ready by the time you return to the resort.""
column3: s:478:""An early morning wake-up call followed by tea/coffee. The early morning tour provides you one of the best times to see the wildlife at its best with bird watching, jeep safari and jungle walk. After breakfast a 45-minute walk through the grassland and forest upstream of the Narayani River. Climb aboard the local boats to observe crocodiles along the banks while floating back to the camp to enjoy lunch. Late afternoon you would be entertained with the Tharu Cultural Program.""
column5: s:338:""An early morning wake-up call followed by tea/coffee. After morning tea we would be going for bird watching as Chitwan is very famous also for the different species of the birds, which is the attracting fact for the visitor. After that we would be back to resort, have breakfast and get ready to head back to Kathmandu by tourist vehicle.""
column7: s:1783:""Your sightseeing trip will start after breakfast. We provide a private vehicle and a professional tour guide. The places we visit are UNESCO World Heritage Sites of:

column1: It lies about 6 kms east of Kathmandu and is the largest stupa in the valley. It looms 36 meters high and presents one of the most fascinating specimens of stupa design. Buddhanath is also known as Khasti, or dew drops, after an account that builders had to use dew to mix the mortar as Kathmandu was suffering from a severe drought during the construction of Bouddhanath.

The temple watches over the valley from the top of a hillock on its western side. The huge stupa is one of the holiest Buddhist sites in Nepal and its establishment is linked to the creation of the Kathmandu Valley out of a primordial lake. Swayambhu is also known as Samhengu and the Monkey temple because of the countless monkeys living in the premises.

Pashupatinath is one of the most sacred Hindu shrines in the world and lies 5 kms east of the city center. The richly-ornamented pagoda houses the sacred Linga, or phallic symbol, of Lord Shiva. Chronicles indicate the temple’s existence prior to 400 AD. Devotees can be seen taking ritual dips in the holy Bagmati River flowing beside the temple.

This complex of palaces, courtyards and temples, built between the 12th and 18th centuries, used to be the seat of the ancient Malla kings of Kathmandu. An intriguing piece here is the 17th- century stone inscription set into the wall of the palace with writings in 15 languages. The Durbar Square is the social, religious and urban focal point of the city. There are also three museums inside the palace building.""
column3: s:683:""Early in the morning, you will be transferred to the domestic airport for your Everest flight. The one-hour flight takes you within the camera range of some of the highest peaks in the world, and cruising this close to the awe-inspiring massifs of rock and ice, is an out-of-this-world experience. This special mountain flight offers the closest possible aerial views of Mt. Everest, Kanchenjunga and many other giants, as well as the Tibetan Plateau.

column1: After returning to Kathmandu, you have the afternoon and the evening to stroll along the streets of Kathmandu for some last-minute shopping. There is a farewell dinner in a typical Nepalese restaurant with cultural performances.""
column3: s:140:""The trip concludes. Our airport representative will drop you at the international airport in Kathmandu for your flight departure from Nepal.""

column14: This includes a final briefing and preparations for the trip. column26: Bhaktapur Durbar Square is a collection of pagoda and shikhara – style temples grouped around a fifty-five-window palace of brick and wood. The attraction of the Bhaktapur Durbar Square is the Lion gate, the Golden gate, the Palace of fifty-five windows, art galleries, and the statue of King Bhupatindra Malla.&lt
column38: The temple is situated on a ridge overlooking the Kathmandu valley, about 12 km east of the city. Dedicated to the Hindu God Vishnu, it is one of the finest and oldest specimens of pagoda architecture built in 323 AD by King Haridatta Verma. The temple is richly decorated with sculptures and carvings, and its position above the Kathmandu valley affords a beautiful view of the surrounding countryside.&lt
column48: Founded in the 7th century, Bungamati is home to one of the most important God of the Kathmandu Valley, Matsyendranath or the God of Rain &amp
column49: Compassion. Worshipped equally by Hindus and Buddhists, the god is accredited by local people with the introduction of rice plantations in the valley. The rich heritage and relatively unchanging lifestyle of the Newar people are clear to see both in Bungamati and in the nearby village of Khokana, which we also visit.&lt
column61: Patan Durbar Square is an enchanting combination of palace buildings, artistic courtyards and graceful pagoda temples. The former royal palace complex is the center of Patan’s religious and social life, and houses a museum containing an array of bronze statues and religious objects. One remarkable monument here is a 17th-century temple dedicated to the Hindu god Krishna, built entirely of stone.&lt
column69: We will then have an hour of scenic drive to Nagarkot, famous for its vantage point of mountains and sunrise and sunset.&lt
column75: After an early breakfast we head to Pokhara on a tourist vehicle which is about six to seven hours drive. The notorious Prithvi Highway, which winds through 206 km of classic Middle Hills countryside, should be seen as more than just a painful bus ride.&lt
column81: Your sightseeing trip will start after breakfast. We provide a private vehicle and a professional tour guide. The places we visit are as below:&lt
column93: Lies in the center of religious old bazaar. It is dedicated to Goddess Bhagawati, yet another manifestation of Shakti. The park grounds offer a fine picnic and relaxing area.&lt

column117: Locally known as Patale Chhango, these amazing waterfalls lie in the southern flank of the Pokhara. Here  the stream flowing from Phewa lake collapses and surges down the rock into a deep gorge, leaping through several potholes. This is hugely popular with tourists and locals alike.&lt
column129: The revered Gupteswar Cave is situated 2 kms from Pokhara airport. The entrance is right across from Davis Falls and the cave is almost 3 kms long. This cave holds special value to Hindus since a phallic symbol of Lord Shiva is preserved here in the condition it was discovered.&lt
column141: Lies at the north of the Pokhara valley. It is a large limestone cave which is one of the few stalagmites stalactite caves found in Nepal.&lt
column151: During the tour, we will visit two different museums: one museum displays the lifestyles and history of the Gurungs, Thakalis and Tharu, while the other, Gurkha Memorial Museum, is dedicated to the famous Gurkha Warriors who earned their name in many fierce battles fought during the World Wars and numerous operations around the world since 1815. The soldiers of the Gurkha regiment won 13 Victoria Cross medals awarded for exceptional bravery shown in the field.&lt
column163: Situated at an altitude of 800m above sea level, Phewa is the second largest lake in the kingdom.  The Barahi Island Temple, which lies in the middle of the lake, is dedicated to the Goddess Barahi. This two-storied pagoda temple is dedicated to the female force Shakti. The reflection of Mt. Machhapuchhare and Annapurna can be seen in its serene water. Thick forest lies on the adjoining southern slopes of the lake.&lt
column175: Carved by Seti-Gandaki, the gorge is one of the natural wonders of Pokhara. K.I. Singh bridge at Bagar, Mahendrapool &amp
column176: Prithivi highway Bridge near bus park, provides a perfect view of the river’s dreadful rush and the deep gorge made by the turbulent flow of white water.&lt
column188: The Tibetan village Tashiling in the south and the Tashi Palkhiel village in the north of Pokhara are renowned for the production and trade of woolen carpets and other handicrafts. The original Tibetan settlers in this region migrated to Nepal in the ‘50s.&lt
column194: Wake up early to catch the sunrise from Sarangkot Hill.&lt
column202: A drive of 45 minutes with 25 minutes hike brings us to the view point of Sarangkot. It is the best spot in Pokhara to view the Himalayas. Get mesmerized with the magical sight of the golden sun rising over white spires of the Annapurna range, Dhaulagiri and Machhapucchre (Fishtail Peak), including views of the beautiful the Pokhara Valley and Phewa Lake. It takes about 15-minute walk down and 45 minutes’ drive to the hotel in Pokhara. Return to hotel for breakfast.&lt
column210: Drive to Chitwan National Park afterward. Upon reaching Chitwan National Park resort, you would be briefed by our Guest Relations Officer. After the lunch you would be going for Village tour. Meanwhile the dinner would be ready by the time you return to the resort.&lt
column216: An early morning wake-up call followed by tea/coffee. The early morning tour provides you one of the best times to see the wildlife at its best with bird watching, jeep safari and jungle walk. After breakfast a 45-minute walk through the grassland and forest upstream of the Narayani River. Climb aboard the local boats to observe crocodiles along the banks while floating back to the camp to enjoy lunch. Late afternoon you would be entertained with the Tharu Cultural Program.&lt
column222: An early morning wake-up call followed by tea/coffee. column5: s:3163:""In a tour, the vehicle transfers all the heavy items and equipments. But the Personal belongings of the clients which is required at any moment like money, water bottle, camera, suns cream and toilet paper etc. should be carried by yourself. It is therefore advisable that you pack the personal belongings into your daypack.

column3: Duffel or Rucksack bag or suitcase&lt
Warm wool or synthetic hat that cover your ears (only if you are travelling in the cold season i.e January, February and December)&lt
Goggles or sunglasses for sunbeam, dust and wind.&lt
A neck warmer is another piece of gear for extra warmth if you feel you will need it and is for cold season i.e January, February and December.&lt
1 pair warm gloves (This is required if your are travelling in cold season i.e January, February and December).&lt
Waterproof (preferably breathable fabric) shell jacket (preferable if you are travelling in rainy season from June to September)&lt
2 pairs lightweight long underwear/thermals (if you are traveling in winter January, February and December)&lt
2 pairs of liner socks, synthetic or capilene&lt
1 pair light camping shoes or sneakers&lt

column1: Please note our guide will also carry the first aid kit bag during the tour. However we still recommend you to bring your personal first aid kit as well.

column3: Extra Strength Excedrin for altitude related headaches.&lt
Ibuprofen for general aches and pains.&lt
Immodium or Pepto bismol capsules for upset stomach or diarrhea.&lt

1 small personal sized first-aid kit with blister treatments such as mole skin, band-aids, some waterproof tape, anti-infection ointments, etc. Your guides will have more extensive medical gear, but you should have the basics for general use.&lt
Passport and extra passport photos (4 copies).&lt
Airline ticket (Please make a copy and leave on at our office in Kathmandu just in case if you need to change the date of your).&lt
Durable wallet / pouch for travel documents, money &amp

Lip balm. At least SPF 20, 2 sticks. A string taped to the stick is helpful, to hang around your neck and some are now being sold with a cord already attached. Handy as it avoids you from having to stop and look for it.&lt

column3: s:481:""Our tour staff will arrive at your hotel at 6:30am in the morning to pick you up. The bus to Pokhara will leave at around 7.30am. Pokhara is a beautiful valley, with panoramic views of Annapurna, Machapuchare (shape of fish tail) in the north, Dhaulagiri in the west, Lamjung Himal and Manaslu in the east. The town of Pokhara is set on the banks of the Phewa Lake. It is smaller and much less hectic than Kathmandu providing the perfect getaway for our tour. Overnight at a hotel.""

column7: s:230:""You will be met by our Bhutanese airport representative on arrival after all the formalities we take a scenic 90 minute drive to the Bhutan’s capital Thimphu and transfer to your hotel for you to settle in. Overnight at a hotel.""
column9: s:596:""Sightseeing in and around Thimphu valley we visit the National Library, which holds a collection of ancient Buddhist texts and manuscripts, as well as the institute for Zorig Chusum commonly known as Painting School, textile and Folk Heritage Museum which provides an insight into Bhutanese material culture and everyday way of life. Also visiting the National Memorial Chorten, Tashichho dzong an impressive monastery, Bhutanese Handicrafts displaying a wide range of beautifully hand-woven textiles and craft products. In the evening we explore the vibrant Thimphu Bazaar. Overnight at a hotel.""
column11: s:743:""Leaving Thimphu we drive about 3 hours, with the road climbing steeply through a forest of pine and cedar, festooned with hanging lichen high up near the Dochula Pass (3,050m). This pass offers panoramic views of the Himalayan mountain ranges on a clear day. You will see rhododendrons, magnolias, junipers and pine forests with chirping sounds of the many rare species of birds found in Bhutan. We drive onto Lobesa to take a short hike to Chimi Lhakhang Temple, it is believed that this temple blesses women who seek fertility. Driving North to the majestic Punakha Dzong, built in 1637 which strategically occupies the land between the two rivers Phochu and Mochu. After our day of sightseeing we head back to Thimphu. Overnight at a hotel.""
column13: s:609:""An early morning drive towards Paro we stop to visit the Ta Dzong which houses the National Museum and visit Paro’s Rimpung Dzong, along the way down we cross the 16th century cantilever bridge. Also visiting the Drugyel Dzong victory fortress, built in 1647 which is 18 kms from Paro. Explore the magnificent ramparts of the erstwhile fortress which defended the country against several incursions. On a clear day one can also view the sacred Mount Jomolhari, from the northern battlements. We take a visit to a farm house and observe the traditional Bhutanese way of life and living. Overnight at a hotel.""
column15: s:588:""The trail to the Tiger’s Nest climbs through beautiful Pine and rhododendron forests. You stop at the cafeteria which offers magnificent up close views of the tigers nest for refreshments. Then we continue the hike for short while until you see Taktsang monastery. Built in 1600s, this incredible monastery clings to the edge of a sheer rock cliff that plunges 900 meters into the valley below. History states that Guru Padmasambhava, the Tantric mystic who brought Buddhism to Bhutan, landed here on the back of a flying tiger and meditated here for three months. Overnight at a hotel.""
column17: s:129:""After breakfast our airport representative will drop you at the Paro International Airport for your flight departure from Bhutan.""
column22: Our airport representative will be receiving you at Tribhuvan International airport. You will be then transferred to your respective hotel in our private tourist vehicle.&lt
column28: This includes a final briefing and preparations for the trip. For the meeting, please make sure you bring your passport, two copies of passport-size photos, and a readable copy of your travel insurance policy. After the pre-trip meeting, your sightseeing trip will start. You will have a private vehicle and a professional tour guide at your disposal.&lt
column44: Bhaktapur Durbar Square is a collection of pagoda and shikhara – style temples grouped around a fifty-five-window palace of brick and wood. The attraction of the Bhaktapur Durbar Square is the Lion gate, the Golden gate, the Palace of fifty-five windows, art galleries, and the statue of King Bhupatindra Malla.&lt
column60: The temple is situated on a ridge overlooking the Kathmandu valley, about 12 km east of the city. Dedicated to the Hindu God Vishnu, it is one of the finest and oldest specimens of pagoda architecture built in 323 AD by King Haridatta Verma. The temple is richly decorated with sculptures and carvings, and its position above the Kathmandu valley affords a beautiful view of the surrounding countryside.&lt
column74: Founded in the 7th century, Bungamati is home to one of the most important God of the Kathmandu Valley, Matsyendranath or the God of Rain &amp
column75: Compassion. Worshipped equally by Hindus and Buddhists, the god is accredited by local people with the introduction of rice plantations in the valley. The rich heritage and relatively unchanging lifestyle of the Newar people are clear to see both in Bungamati and in the nearby village of Khokana, which we also visit.&lt
column91: Patan Durbar Square is an enchanting combination of palace buildings, artistic courtyards and graceful pagoda temples. The former royal palace complex is the center of Patan’s religious and social life, and houses a museum containing an array of bronze statues and religious objects. One remarkable monument here is a 17th-century temple dedicated to the Hindu god Krishna, built entirely of stone.&lt
column99: We will then have an hour of scenic drive to Nagarkot, famous for its vantage point of mountains and sunrise and sunset.&lt
column105: Our tour staff will arrive at your hotel at 6:30am in the morning to pick you up. The bus to Pokhara will leave at around 7.30am. Pokhara is a beautiful valley, with panoramic views of Annapurna, Machapuchare (shape of fish tail) in the north, Dhaulagiri in the west, Lamjung Himal and Manaslu in the east. The town of Pokhara is set on the banks of the Phewa Lake. It is smaller and much less hectic than Kathmandu providing the perfect getaway for our tour. Overnight at a hotel.&lt
column111: Your sightseeing trip will start after breakfast. We provide a private vehicle and a professional tour guide. The places we visit are as below:&lt
column127: Lies in the center of religious old bazaar. It is dedicated to Goddess Bhagawati, yet another manifestation of Shakti. The park grounds offer a fine picnic and relaxing area.&lt
column143: The two lakes lie in the north-east of the Pokhara valley at a distance of 13kms from the main city of Pokhara. These lakes are located at the foothill of Begnas, mountain and are separated by the Pachabiya hill.&lt
column159: Locally known as Patale Chhango, these amazing waterfalls lie in the southern flank of the Pokhara. Here the stream flowing from Phewa lake collapses and surges down the rock into a deep gorge, leaping through several potholes. This is hugely popular with tourists and locals alike.&lt
column175: The revered Gupteswar Cave is situated 2 kms from Pokhara airport. The entrance is right across from Davis Falls and the cave is almost 3 kms long. It has some big hall-sized rooms and some passages where you have to crawl on all four. This cave holds special value to Hindus since a phallic symbol of Lord Shiva is preserved here in the condition it was discovered.&lt
column191: Lies at the north of the Pokhara valley. It is a large limestone cave which is one of the few stalagmites stalactite caves found in Nepal.&lt
column205: During the tour, we will visit two different museums: one museum displays the lifestyles and history of the Gurungs, Thakalis and Tharu, while the other, Gurkha Memorial Museum, is dedicated to the famous Gurkha Warriors who earned their name in many fierce battles fought during the World Wars and numerous operations around the world since 1815. The soldiers of the Gurkha regiment won 13 Victoria Cross medals awarded for exceptional bravery shown in the field.&lt
column221: Situated at an altitude of 800m above sea level, Phewa is the second largest lake in the kingdom. The Barahi Island Temple, which lies in the middle of the lake, is dedicated to the Goddess Barahi. This two-storied pagoda temple is dedicated to the female force Shakti. The reflection of Mt. Machhapuchhare and Annapurna can be seen in its serene water. Thick forest lies on the adjoining southern slopes of the lake.&lt
column237: Carved by Seti-Gandaki, the gorge is one of the natural wonders of Pokhara. K.I. Singh bridge at Bagar, Mahendrapool &amp
column238: Prithivi highway Bridge near bus park, provides a perfect view of the river’s dreadful rush and the deep gorge made by the turbulent flow of white water.&lt
column254: The Tibetan village Tashiling in the south and the Tashi Palkhiel village in the north of Pokhara are renowned for the production and trade of woolen carpets and other handicrafts. The original Tibetan settlers in this region migrated to Nepal in the ‘50s.&lt
column260: Wake up early to catch the sunrise from Sarangkot Hill.&lt
column276: A drive of 45 minutes with 25 minutes hike brings us to the view point of Sarangkot. It is the best spot in Pokhara to view the Himalayas. Get mesmerized with the magical sight of the golden sun rising over white spires of the Annapurna range, Dhaulagiri and Machhapucchre (Fishtail Peak), including views of the beautiful the Pokhara Valley and Phewa Lake. It takes about 15-minute walk down and 45 minutes’ drive to the hotel in Pokhara. Return to hotel for breakfast.&lt
column284: Drive to Chitwan National Park afterward. Upon reaching Chitwan National Park resort, you would be briefed by our Guest Relations Officer. After the lunch you would be going for Village tour. Meanwhile the dinner would be ready by the time you return to the resort.&lt
column290: An early morning wake-up call followed by tea/coffee. The early morning tour provides you one of the best times to see the wildlife at its best with bird watching, jeep safari and jungle walk. After breakfast a 45-minute walk through the grassland and forest upstream of the Narayani River. Climb aboard the local boats to observe crocodiles along the banks while floating back to the camp to enjoy lunch. Late afternoon you would be entertained with the Tharu Cultural Program.&lt
column296: An early morning wake-up call followed by tea/coffee. After morning tea we would be going for bird watching as Chitwan is very famous also for the different species of the birds, which is the attracting fact for the visitor. After that we would be back to resort, have breakfast and get ready to head back to Kathmandu by tourist vehicle.&lt
column302: You will be met by our Bhutanese airport representative on arrival after all the formalities we take a scenic 90 minute drive to the Bhutan’s capital Thimphu and transfer to your hotel for you to settle in. Overnight at a hotel.&lt
column308: Sightseeing in and around Thimphu valley we visit the National Library, which holds a collection of ancient Buddhist texts and manuscripts, as well as the institute for Zorig Chusum commonly known as Painting School, textile and Folk Heritage Museum which provides an insight into Bhutanese material culture and everyday way of life. Also visiting the National Memorial Chorten, Trashichho dzong an impressive monastery, Bhutanese Handicrafts displaying a wide range of beautifully hand-woven textiles and craft products. In the evening we explore the vibrant Thimphu Bazaar. Overnight at a hotel.&lt
column314: Leaving Thimphu we drive about 3 hours, with the road climbing steeply through a forest of pine and cedar, festooned with hanging lichen high up near the Dochula Pass (3,050m). This pass offers panoramic views of the Himalayan mountain ranges on a clear day. You will see rhododendrons, magnolias, junipers and pine forests with chirping sounds of the many rare species of birds found in Bhutan. We drive onto Lobesa to take a short hike to Chimi Lhakhang Temple, it is believed that this temple blesses women who seek fertility. Driving North to the majestic Punakha Dzong, built in 1637 which strategically occupies the land between the two rivers Phochu and Mochu. After our day of sightseeing we head back to Thimphu. Overnight at a hotel.&lt
column320: An early morning drive towards Paro we stop to visit the Ta Dzong which houses the National Museum and visit Paro’s Rimpung Dzong, along the way down we cross the 16th century cantilever bridge. Also visiting the Drugyel Dzong victory fortress, built in 1647 which is 18 kms from Paro. Explore the magnificent ramparts of the erstwhile fortress which defended the country against several incursions. On a clear day one can also view the sacred Mount Jomolhari, from the northern battlements. We take a visit to a farm house and observe the traditional Bhutanese way of life and living. Overnight at a hotel.&lt
column326: The trail to the Tiger’s Nest climbs through beautiful Pine and rhododendron forests. You stop at the cafeteria which offers magnificent up close views of the tigers nest for refreshments. Then we continue the hike for short while until you see Taktsang monastery. Built in 1600s, this incredible monastery clings to the edge of a sheer rock cliff that plunges 900 meters into the valley below. History states that Guru Padmasambhava, the Tantric mystic who brought Buddhism to Bhutan, landed here on the back of a flying tiger and meditated here for three months. Overnight at a hotel.&lt
column332: After breakfast our airport representative will drop you at the Paro International Airport for your flight departure from Bhutan.&lt

column49: >","This Magical Nepal Bhutan Tour bridges many traditional landmarks and cultural customs of both Nepalese and Bhutanese people. The skills of the local artisans are so vivid in the handicrafts. It never fails to amaze visitors to these two Himalayan kingdoms.","Immerse yourself in the fascination throughout the colorful array of rich historic heritage, exquisite religious sites in this Nepal Bhutan tour.",,"a:30:{s:6:""enable""

column1:
1351,"Spectacular Mardi Himal Trek","

Mardi Himal Trek is an unseen gem and a rarely explored trekking destination in Nepal. Unlike other trekking trails, this trek is less crowded by the numbers of tourists even in the favorable season.  Mardi Himal ridges to have an up-close view of the mountains and the green luscious forest at Forest Camp. Rarely is mountain trekking this easy and this spectacular.

Mardi Himal Trek is not much challenging and has good trails. Few of the times, the sections are quite steep but at the other times, the ridges are grassy and easy to walk. The maximum altitude for the trek is 4500m at the viewpoint or the Mardi Himal Base Camp. The panoramic view of the mountains Annapurna South and Machhapuchhre (Fishtail) will make you feel heavenly and rejuvenate the tired body. This trek will also impress you with the flora, fauna, wildlife, the green rich forests of Oak and Maple and the gorgeous national flower Rhododendron along the trails. Mardi Himal trek is simply the best trek not only for the views of the mountains but also to discover the traditional village life and the true countryside of Nepal.

column3: Moderate trek yet the finest panoramic views of Himalayan ranges like Mt. Fishtail and Annapurna South.&lt
Gradually increase in altitude which makes the trekking less strenuous.&lt
Richly green forests with vibrant flowers like oak, maple, including the national flower rhododendron.&lt
Exotic trekking trail due to less number of tourists&lt
The real taste of remote Nepal&lt

column1: Two clients share one porter. We will supply you a trek duffel bag where you keep your heavy items and this bag is carried by the porter. You will need to bring your own daypack to be carried by you. In the daypack, you can put money, important documents, water bottle/bladder, camera, toiletries, sunscreen, notebook, etc.

The weight limit for the porter is 30 kg or 66 pounds. 15 kg or 33 pounds for each client. So, we recommend you to pack as carefully as you can and not exceed the weight limit. You can leave your non-trekking stuff at the locker facility in the Kathmandu hotel.

column3: Sleeping bag (We can provide one if you need it but has to be returned after the trek)&lt
Wool or synthetic hat that cover the ears (For winter)&lt

column1: (Please note our guide will carry the first-aid kit bag during the trek. However we still recommend you to bring your personalized first-aid kit as well.)

column3: Extra Strength Excedrin for altitude related headaches&lt
Ibuprofen for general aches and pains&lt
Immodium or Pepto bismol capsules for upset stomach or diarrhea&lt
Passport and extra passport photos (3 copies)&lt
Airline tickets (Please make a copy and leave one at our office in Kathmandu just in case if you need to change the date of yours)&lt
Durable wallet/pouch for travel documents, money &amp
Toiletry kit (Be sure to include toilet paper stored in a plastic bag, hand wipes, and liquid hand sanitizer, towel, soap, etc.)&lt
Favorite snack foods (No more than 2 pounds)&lt
Cameras (Memory cards, chargers and also batteries)&lt
Pee bottle for men and pee funnel for women&lt

column36: s:304:""You could be already in Kathmandu or you may be arriving on this very day, anyway, we welcome you to Nepal! On this first day we transfer you to your hotel and brief you about the trek if the time permits. You will not do much except observing the ambiance around you and get acquainted with the country.""
column38: s:470:""An early morning drive on a tourist bus takes you to Pokhara, the city of lakes. Pokhara is at a distance of 200 km from Kathmandu. It takes almost 6-7 hours to reach to this beautiful city. The drive will give you an opportunity to have a look at the beauty of flora, fauna, the diverse demography, beautiful mountain ranges, the raging Trishuli, Marshyangdi Rivers and plenty of rivulets along the way. As soon as you reach Pokhara, you will be transferred to a hotel.""
column40: s:440:""After breakfast we head out for Kande on a jeep. The drive to Kande where our trek begins is of 1 hour. As we reach there, we begin our trek on the beautiful trail and walk upwards to the Australian Base Camp for about 3 hours. Australian Camp is a beautiful village best known, where on a clear day you can see an unobstructed view of the Himalayan Mountains of Annapurna range, Machhapuchhre, Manaslu range and also beautiful green hills.""
column42: s:482:""After breakfast in the morning, we head out to reach Forest Camp which will take almost 6 to 7 hours of walk. The trail is slightly downhill from Base Camp to Pothana (1950 m) and again ascends to Deurali (2100 m). At Deurali there is a signboard pointing towards right saying “Forest Camp”. This will be the path we follow to reach the destination. The trail enters a quiet jungle of oak trees, maples, rhododendrons etc. After walking for few more hours, we reach Forest Camp.""
column44: s:415:""After walking a steep climb for about few hours, we are out of the forest and onto a grassy ridge. The ridge is sometimes full of snow. The mountains seem to grow closer to you as you walk towards the Low Camp. After walking for around 6 to 7 hours you reach Low Camp at the afternoon. Enjoying a good sip of tea, you can acclimatize and capture the best views of the up close Annapurna South and Mt. Machhapuchhre.""
column46: s:410:""We wake up early this day for the beautiful view of sunrise through the mountains. After early breakfast, we head on to the trekking trails. We walk on the grassy ridges which during winters are filled with snow. The trail ascends throughout the walk up to the High Camp. We walk above the tree line and the temperature reduces along the path. After walking for almost 4 to 5 hours, we finally reach High Camp.""
column48: s:549:""Today we wake up early and walk for few hours to reach the Mardi Himal Base Camp. The view of the Annapurna Sanctuary can be clearly seen. The panoramic scenes of South face of Mt. Annapurna and Mt. Machhapuchhre (Fishtail) will be worth every steps taken to the Base Camp. After spending few hours here, we return back to the High Camp for lunch. After having lunch and resting for some time at High camp, we walk down to Low Camp from where it is about an hour or two’s walk to Bada Danda. We will be staying at the teahouse at Bada Danda today.""
column50: s:385:""After breakfast we start walking towards Forest Camp from where we will be taking a side trail down to the beautiful village of Landruk. The elevation changes drastically while walking down to Landruk. Landruk is a Gurung village with traditional houses that witnesses the immensely beautiful view of snow peak Annapurna South. After walking for around 6 to hours we reach the village.""
column52: s:299:""Today is the last day of trekking. We start our day with a descent down the trail to Syauli Bazar. The hike will be quite tough with many steep steps down. On arrival at Syauli Bazar we drive to Pokhara in a public vehicle. Upon reaching Pokhara, we celebrate the successful trek to the Mardi Himal.""
column54: s:370:""We head out for Kathmandu in a tourist bus. Enjoying the last glimpse of the beautiful Himalayas, we return back to Kathmandu. The journey will be of 7 total hours. Upon arrival at Kathmandu, our representative will meet and transfer you back to the hotel.

column1: In the evening we will have a farewell dinner in a traditional Nepalese restaurant with cultural performances.""
column3: s:138:""The trip ends, our Airport Representative will drop you to the Kathmandu International Airport for your final flight departure from Nepal.""

column32: After walking a steep climb for about few hours, we are out of the forest and onto a grassy ridge. The ridge is sometimes full of snow. The mountains seem to grow closer to you as you walk towards the Low Camp. After walking for around 6 to 7 hours you reach Low Camp at the afternoon. Enjoying a good sip of tea, you can acclimatize and capture the best views of the up close Annapurna South and Mt. Machhapuchhre.&lt
column38: We wake up early this day for the beautiful view of sunrise through the mountains. After early breakfast, we head on to the trekking trails. We walk on the grassy ridges which during winters are filled with snow. The trail ascends throughout the walk up to the High Camp. We walk above the tree line and the temperature reduces along the path. After walking for almost 4 to 5 hours, we finally reach High Camp.&lt
column44: Today we wake up early and walk for few hours to reach the Mardi Himal Base Camp. The view of the Annapurna Sanctuary can be clearly seen. The panoramic scenes of South face of Mt. Annpaurna and Mt. Machhapuchhre (Fishtail) will be worth every steps taken to the Base Camp. After spending few hours here, we return back to the High Camp for lunch. After having lunch and resting for some time at High camp, we walk down to Low Camp from where it is about an hour or two’s walk to Badaldanda. We will be staying at the teahouse at Badaldanda today.&lt
column50: After breakfast we start walking towards Forest Camp from where we will be taking a side trail down to the beautiful village of Landruk. The elevation changes drastically while walking down to Landruk. Landruk is a Gurung village with traditional houses that witnesses the immensely beautiful view of snow peak Annapurna South. After walking for around 6 to hours we reach the village.&lt
column56: Today is the last day of trekking. We start our day with a descent down the trail to Syauli Bazar. The hike will be quite tough with many steep steps down. On arrival at Syauli Bazar we drive to Pokhara in a public vehicle. Upon reaching Pokhara, we celebrate the successful trek to the Mardi Himal.&lt
column62: We head out for Kathmandu in a tourist bus. Enjoying the last glimpse of the beautiful Himalayas, we return back to Kathmandu. The journey will be of 7 total hours. Upon arrival at Kathmandu, our representative will meet and transfer you back to the hotel.&lt
column70: In the evening we will have a farewell dinner in a traditional Nepalese restaurant with cultural performances.&lt
column76: The trip ends, our Airport Representative will drop you to the Kathmandu International Airport for your final flight departure from Nepal.&lt

column1: 1406,"Nepal Yoga Meditation Retreat & Hiking","Nepal has been one of the popular destination for a quick fix of spiritual enlightenment among international tourism. Wonderful mountains, dramatic landscapes, magnificent cultures, and tradition carry a huge spiritual significance to treat ownself after hectic working days.

column2: Trekking Retreat facilitates for all age group. It is a unique opportunity for those interested in the strengthening of both the body and mind. The combination of these elements creates a more fulfilling physical exercise while strengthening and opening the mind for greater relaxation and awareness all within the beautiful natural environment in the Himalayas.

column24: s:339:""Our airport representative will be receiving you at Tribhuvan International airport, Kathmandu. You will be then transferred to your respective hotel in our private tourist vehicle. In the evening, you will be practicing your first yoga and meditation glass with guru. Afterwards, we will have dinner together and sightseeing in Kathmandu.""
column26: s:864:""First thing in the morning, you will be given massage to soothe tired muscles with the energizing hands of our traditionally trained Ayurvedic Masseuse.  We’ll then ask you to join our purpose designed yoga sessions are for beginners through to advanced yogis. The aim of which is to open your lungs and rejuvenate your circulatory system, pushing much needed oxygen to your cells to restore your vital energy.

column1: Your morning yoga session begins with simple physical exercise to a larger spiritual value of life, connecting human value to super consciousness. We learn a real art of living performing yoga and meditation.

Afterwards, we take one hour drive to Nagarkot directly to view the beautiful sunrise with the fresh glance of the magnificent views of the mountains. There are several pleasant strolls to explore the local village and surroundings too.""
column3: s:1077:""Wake up early in the morning and we will perform nose cleansing. After nose cleansing, one can benefit from breathing exercises. Your lungs and the respiratory passage will be cleaned and supply the blood with more oxygen. As a harmonic conclusion of such a small program, you can do “The alternate nostril breathing” to gain an even better balance and clarity in the brain.

column1: Jamacho is one of the popular short hikes in Nepal. At the top of a hill in Shivapuri National Park, there is a Buddhist shrine called Jamacho Gumba. A view tower stands there which offers a bird’s-eye view of the Kathmandu valley and on a clear day you can see the magnificent Himalayas in the north. And on a smaller hill below you can see Swayambhunath aka the Monkey Temple.

In the early evening, as the setting sun turns the lake a silvery purple beneath, it means time for yin yoga. You will be led through moon salutations – a sequence of 14 stretches. The final session of the day involves chanting Sanskrit mantras, with Mantra playing a harmonium and guru thrumming tabla drums.""
column3: s:795:""In this very last day, we'll find your breath within Asana (postures) &amp
column4: Pranayama, whilst stretching your back, quads, hamstrings &amp
column5: calves - all necessary for you to achieve your goal. We'll work together to strengthen your immunity system and psychological tolerance for hard work you've planned ahead.

column1: You will also be given a philosophy lesson as Yoga classes contribute to the development of a healthy body, a healthy mind, and healthy thought. It also helps one achieve a balanced, harmonious and integrated development of all the aspects of their personalities. Yoga is a pathway to true, happy, and healthy living.
At the afternoon, the trip concludes. Our airport representative will drop you at the international airport in Kathmandu for your flight departure from Nepal.""

column1: 1481,"Everest Base Camp Khumbu Icefall Trek","Everybody wants to see a glimpse of the world’s highest mountain once in a lifetime. That’s the reason why the Everest Base Camp Trek is so popular. The trek has a number of stunning attractions including many gompas(monasteries), lovely villages, Tibetan lifestyle and of course the almighty Everest.  The breathtaking flight from Kathmandu takes you right into Lukla, the heart of high-himalayan ranges.  The friendly Sherpa people of Solu region truly make your trip incredible.

and the friendly Sherpa people of the Solu Khumbu region make trekking through the area a joy. You will also see the remarkable views of Khumbu Icefall when you hike up to Everest Base Camp and Khumbu Glacier.

[sharethis-inline-buttons]",,20181113,trip,http://trekkingtopnepal.com/trip/everest-base-camp-khumbu-icefall-trek/,http://trekkingtopnepal.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/27897439605_d3493c9844_k.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544804013/Ama-Dablam-Khumjung-Nepal_mqc5cz.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544804013/Amadablam-Expedition-%E0%A4%95%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A0%E0%A4%AE%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%A1%E0%A5%8C%E0%A4%81-Nepal_cyqsvr.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544804013/Athabasca-Glacier-Canada_ola40n.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544804013/Dughla-Nepal_b358g7.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544804012/ebc-jacket_zgnoaz.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803988/Everest-Base-Camp-Trekking-Rte-Khumjung-Nepal_ec5mrk.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803988/Everest-Base-Camp-Khumjung-Nepal_mx96cn.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803988/Gorak-Shep-Khumjung-Nepal_iocuz0.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803987/Kala-Patthar-Khumjung-Nepal_t6ro9p.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803987/Khumbu-Valley-Namche-Nepal_ui2eph.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803987/Langtang-National-Park-Nepal_dj6b01.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803986/nepal_e3l8pa.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803986/nepal2_vvzazn.jpg|http://trekkingtopnepal.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/2579840888_4799e2148d_b.jpg|http://trekkingtopnepal.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/4660663983_aaab382e89_o.jpg|http://trekkingtopnepal.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/6104072099_00e3ef8f19_o.jpg|http://trekkingtopnepal.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/7648502640_991e2c8a8a_o.jpg|http://trekkingtopnepal.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/ column3: One of the most adventurous treks in the Everest Himalayas.&lt
Unique trek that goes through Lukla, Namche Bazaar, Gokyo, Cho La Pass(5330m), Kala Patthar (5550m) and Everest Base Camp.&lt
Leads you to the home of brave and legendary Sherpa people&lt
Offers the finest panoramic views of Mt. Makalu, Mt. Cho Oyu, Mt. Lhotse.&lt
Experience trekking through the fast-flowing and rushing Dudh Koshi river that originates from the glaciers of Everest Region.&lt

column1: Two clients share one porter. We will supply you a trek duffel bag where you keep your heavy items and this bag is carried by the porter. You will need to bring your own daypack to be carried by you. In the daypack, you can put money, important documents, water bottle/bladder, camera, toiletries, sunscreen, notebook, etc.

The weight limit for Kathmandu-Lukla-Kathmandu flights is 15 kg or 33 pounds. This is combining both the duffel bag and the daypack. If you exceed this limit, you will have to pay an additional fee. When this happens, sometimes the airline sends your bag in later flights and this can be very problematic for many reasons. So, we recommend you to pack as carefully as you can and not exceed the weight limit. You can leave your non-trekking stuff at the locker facility in the Kathmandu hotel.

column3: 4-season sleeping bag (We can provide one if you need it but has to be returned after the trek.)&lt
Down jacket (Must have for mornings, nights and evenings, and for altitudes above 4,000 m
column4: We can provide it if you need one but has to be returned after the trek.)&lt

column3: Wool or synthetic hat that cover the ears&lt
Soft shell and hard shell trekking pants&lt

column1: Please note our guide will carry the first-aid kit bag during the trek. However we still recommend you to bring your personalized first-aid kit as well.

column3: Extra Strength Excedrin for altitude related headaches&lt
Ibuprofen for general aches and pains&lt
Immodium or Pepto Bismol capsules for upset stomach or diarrhea&lt
Diamox (commonly prescribed as Acetazolamide) 125 or 250mg tablets for altitude sickness&lt

column5: Passport and extra passport photos (3 copies)&lt

column3: Airline ticket (Please make a copy and leave one at our office in Kathmandu just in case if you need to change the date of your flight.)&lt
Durable wallet/pouch for travel documents, money &amp
Toiletry kit (Be sure to include toilet paper stored in a plastic bag, hand wipes, and liquid hand sanitizer, towel, soap, etc.)&lt
Favorite snack foods (No more than 2 pounds)&lt
Cameras (Memory cards, chargers and also batteries)&lt
Pee bottle for men and pee funnel for women&lt

column45: s:51:""Trek from Gokyo to Thangna (4500m) - approx 4 hours""

column66: s:170:""Our airport representative will be receiving you at Tribhuvan International Airport. You will be then transferred to your respective hotel in our private tourist vehicle.""
column68: s:1389:""After a hearty breakfast, at 8.30 am your sightseeing trip will start. You will have a private vehicle and a professional tour guide at your disposal. Today we will visit some heritages listed below:

column1: Pashupatinath Temple is one of the most significant Hindu temples of Lord Shiva in the world, located on the banks of the Bagmati River. Though you are not allowed to go inside the temple as it is strictly for Hindus only, you can clearly see the temple and the activities from the eastern bank of the Bagmati River. It is a square two-tiered pagoda temple built on a single-tier plinth which is famous all over the world.

Boudhananath is one of the holiest Buddhist sites in Kathmandu. It was built in the 5th century with four pairs of eyes of Lord Buddha in four cardinal directions keeping an eternal watch over the people and their doings. You will find Buddhist pilgrims from Tibet going round the stupa spinning the prayer wheels.

Visit the Bhaktapur Durbar Square, the Royal Residential Quarter of Bhupatindra Malla, famous five-storied temple of Nyatapola in Pagoda style Batsala temple, Bhairavnath temple, Dattatreya temple, Pujari Muth and Palace of 55 windows.
The rest of our time in Kathmandu is free for further exploration and some last-minute shopping in Thamel area for trekking essentials.""
column3: s:670:""An early morning start takes us to the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu for the 35-minute scenic flight to Tenzing and Hillary Airport at Lukla (2804 m). On arrival at the airport, the guide will brief you and introduce our porters before we begin our trek towards Phakding (2610m).

column1: After landing we have time to explore the village while our Sherpa crew sort and load our trekking equipment. Then we begin our trek by descending towards the Dudh Kosi River where we join the main trail to Namche Bazaar, located just above Chaurikharka (2713m). The walking is easy. After passing through the small village of Ghat (2550m), it is a short walk to Phakding.""
column3: s:460:""We continue trekking along the banks of the Dudh Kosi, crossing the majestic river many times on exciting suspension bridges laden with prayer flags. After entering the Sagarmatha National Park, the trail climbs steeply with breathtaking views. Namche Bazaar (considered the Gateway to Everest) is home to many quality restaurants, hotels, lodges, shops, money exchange services, internet cafes and bakeries. Namche is the biggest town along the Everest trail.""
column5: s:421:""We will spend a day in Namche Bazaar in order to acclimatize and adjust to the thinning air. We will trek a short distance to a museum that is celebrated for its exhibits of the traditional customs of the Sherpa people. We will also hike up the Syangboche Airport and the Everest View Hotel, one of the highest-placed hotels in the world. From this point, we can see rewarding views of the Himalayas including Mt Everest.""
column7: s:314:""The trail climbs steeply out of valley through rhododendron forest. Juniper and large conifers start to appear as the elevation increases making the trekking very pristine in spring. The trail passes through Yak Kharkas and summer settlements. The views of Khumbi La and Taboche are magnificent throughout the day.""
column9: s:228:""We climb a ridge for an excellent view both down the valley to Kangtega and up towards Cho Oyu and descend to a river and again climbs steep to the terminal moraine of the Ngozumpa glacier. We will reach Machherma by early noon.""
column11: s:177:""The trek today takes us at one of our main destinations, Gokyo (4790 m). We will make this camp our base for 2 nights as we will have a sightseeing and hiking trip around Gokyo.""
column13: s:381:""Early in the morning, we have a steep climb up to the top of Gokyo Ri at an elevation of 5,483 m. There are ample rewards for those who attempt this trip – you get stunning views of the super Gokyo valley, the massive Ngozumpa glacier and an incredible panoramic view of the whole Khumbu Himalayas, including the giants Everest, Lhotse, Nuptse, Makalu, Cho-Oyu and Gyachung Kang.""
column15: s:133:""Trek to the foot of Cho La pass. Accommodation in Thangna will be very basic and in a dormitory-based room because of its remoteness.""
column17: s:677:""We start walking before sunrise at 4:00 or 5:00 am so as to reach the pass by 9:00 am – 10:00 am and dodge bad weather conditions of the noontime. We cross over at an altitude of 5,300 m where we could be exposed to strong winds if we crossing too late. We start to climb steeply the trail that is regularly used and easy to follow. However, the problem may arise due to the altitude and snow. It often causes terrible problems to cross the pass if it is covered by snow. As you reach the top, you are rewarded by the magnificent views, then we descend to the Dzongla at noon. Accommodation in Dzongla will be very basic and in dormitory-style room because of its remoteness.""
column19: s:93:""A rather easier and shorter trekking route will take us to Lobuche after 4 hours of trekking.""
column21: s:363:""This is a big and difficult day walk along the Khumbu Glacier and up to Everest Base Camp at (5365 m), the closest you can get to Mt. Everest without mountaineering equipment. During spring, there will likely be expedition teams about to attempt the summit. The view of the Khumbu Icefall from Base Camp is spectacular. We return back to Gorak Shep for the night.""
column23: s:501:""This will be one of the most difficult yet rewarding days of the trek. Most of the morning is spent climbing Mt. Kala Patthar, a small peak at 5,555 m. The ascent is demanding but the climber gets the most magnificent mountain panorama: Everest, the highest point on the planet at 8,848 m, towers directly ahead and on all sides loom the giants such as Nuptse, Pumori, Chagatse, Lhotse and countless others. We make a quick descent to Gorak Shep and have hot breakfast, and then trek down to Pheriche.""
column25: s:176:""Leaving the mountains behind us, our descent takes us through Pangboche and Tengboche before continuing to the town of Namche Bazaar. We arrive back to Namche in the afternoon.""
column27: s:341:""This is our last day of trekking as we return to Lukla where the trek began. We enjoy this time to reflect on the trek as a group and the personal achievement of all those who took part. The afternoon is free, so you can wander about, relax and enjoy a hot shower! In the evening, have a few celebratory drinks and dance with your trekmates.""
column29: s:205:""Enjoying the last glimpse of the mountains we have recently visited, the 35 minutes scenic flight takes us back to Kathmandu. On arrival in Kathmandu, we are met and transferred back to our starting hotel.""
column31: s:186:""In the afternoon we will have a farewell lunch with the Ngawang families. The rest of our time in Kathmandu is free for further exploration and buy some souvenirs before going back home.""
column33: s:150:""The trip concludes – our airport representative will drop you to Kathmandu’s Tribhuvan International Airport for your flight departure from Nepal.""
column38: Our airport representative will be receiving you at Tribhuvan International Airport. You will be then transferred to your respective hotel in our private tourist vehicle.&lt
column44: After a hearty breakfast, at 8.30 am your sightseeing trip will start. You will have a private vehicle and a professional tour guide at your disposal. Today we will visit some heritages listed below:&lt
column56: Pashupatinath Temple is one of the most significant Hindu temples of Lord Shiva in the world, located on the banks of the Bagmati River. Though you are not allowed to go inside the temple as it is strictly for Hindus only, you can clearly see the temple and the activities from the eastern bank of the Bagmati River. It is a square two-tiered pagoda temple built on a single-tier plinth which is famous all over the world.&lt
column68: Boudhananath is one of the holiest Buddhist sites in Kathmandu. It was built in the 5th century with four pairs of eyes of Lord Buddha in four cardinal directions keeping an eternal watch over the people and their doings. You will find Buddhist pilgrims from Tibet going round the stupa spinning the prayer wheels.&lt
column80: Visit the Bhaktapur Durbar Square, the Royal Residential Quarter of Bhupatindra Malla, famous five-storied temple of Nyatapola in Pagoda style Batsala temple, Bhairavnath temple, Duttatraya temple, Pujari Muth and Palace of 55 windows.&lt
column88: The rest of our time in Kathmandu is free for further exploration and some last-minute shopping in Thamel area for trekking essentials.&lt
column94: An early morning start takes us to the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu for the 35-minute scenic flight to Tenzing and Hillary Airport at Lukla (2804 m). column102: After landing we have time to explore the village while our Sherpa crew sort and load our trekking equipment. Then we begin our trek by descending towards the Dudh Kosi River where we join the main trail to Namche Bazaar, located just above Chaurikharka (2713m). The walking is easy. After passing through the small village of Ghat (2550m), it is a short walk to Phakding.&lt
column108: We continue trekking along the banks of the Dudh Kosi, crossing the majestic river many times on exciting suspension bridges laden with prayer flags. After entering the Sagamartha National Park, the trail climbs steeply with breathtaking views. Namche Bazaar (considered the Gateway to Everest) is home to many quality restaurants, hotels, lodges, shops, money exchange services, internet cafes and bakeries. Namche is the biggest town along the Everest trail.&lt
column114: We will spend a day in Namche Bazaar in order to acclimatize and adjust to the thinning air. We will trek a short distance to a museum that is celebrated for its exhibits of the traditional customs of the Sherpa people. We will also hike up the Syangboche Airport and the Everest View Hotel, one of the highest-placed hotels in the world. From this point, we can see rewarding views of the Himalayas including Mt Everest.&lt
column120: The trail climbs steeply out of valley through rhododendron forest. Juniper and large conifers start to appear as the elevation increases making the trekking very pristine in spring. The trail passes through Yak Kharkas and summer settlements. The views of Khumbi La and Taboche are magnificent throughout the day.&lt
column126: We climb a ridge for an excellent view both down the valley to Kengtega and up towards Cho Oyu and descend to a river and again climbs steep to the terminal moraine of the Ngozumpa glacier. We will reach Machherma by early noon.&lt
column132: The trek today takes us at one of our main destinations, Gokyo (4790 m). We will make this camp our base for 2 nights as we will have a sightseeing and hiking trip around Gokyo.&lt
column138: Early in the morning, we have a steep climb up to the top of Gokyo Ri at an elevation of 5,483 m. There are ample rewards for those who attempt this trip – you get stunning views of the super Gokyo valley, the massive Ngozumpa glacier and an incredible panoramic view of the whole Khumbu Himalayas, including the giants Everest, Lhotse, Nuptse, Makalu, Cho-Oyu and Gychung Kang.&lt
column144: Trek to the foot of Cho La pass. Accommodation in Thangna will be very basic and in a dormitory-based room because of its remoteness.&lt
column150: We start walking before sunrise at 4:00 or 5:00 am so as to reach the pass by 9:00 am – 10:00 am and dodge bad weather conditions of the noontime. We cross over at an altitude of 5,300 m where we could be exposed to strong winds if we crossing too late. We start to climb steeply the trail that is regularly used and easy to follow. However, the problem may arise due to the altitude and snow. It often causes terrible problems to cross the pass if it is covered by snow. As you reach the top, you are rewarded by the magnificent views, then we descend to the Dzongla at noon. Accommodation in Dzongla will be very basic and in dormitory-style room because of its remoteness.&lt

column162: This is a big and difficult day walk along the Khumbu Glacier and up to Everest Base Camp at (5365 m), the closest you can get to Mt. Everest without mountaineering equipment. During spring, there will likely be expedition teams about to attempt the summit. The view of the Khumbu Icefall from Base Camp is spectacular. We return back to Gorak Shep for the night.&lt
column168: This will be one of the most difficult yet rewarding days of the trek. Most of the morning is spent climbing Mt. Kala Patthar, a small peak at 5,555 m. The ascent is demanding but the climber gets the most magnificent mountain panorama: Everest, the highest point on the planet at 8,848 m, towers directly ahead and on all sides loom the giants such as Nuptse, Pumori, Chagatse, Lhotse and countless others. We make a quick descent to Gorak Shep and have hot breakfast, and then trek down to Pheriche.&lt
column174: Leaving the mountains behind us, our descent takes us through Pangboche and Tengboche before continuing to the town of Namche Bazaar. We arrive back to Namche in the afternoon.&lt
column180: This is our last day of trekking as we return to Lukla where the trek began. We enjoy this time to reflect on the trek as a group and the personal achievement of all those who took part. The afternoon is free, so you can wander about, relax and enjoy a hot shower! In the evening, have a few celebratory drinks and dance with your trekmates.&lt

column192: In the afternoon we will have a farewell lunch with the Ngawang families. The rest of our time in Kathmandu is free for further exploration and buy some souvenirs before going back home.&lt

column1: 1500,"A Taste of Natural: Tsum Valley Trek","Tsum Valley trek is one of the best examples of off-beaten trekking path in Nepal. Since this trekking trail has been discovered just a short time ago, the area is not hugely crowded with people. This makes Tsum Valley one of the finest trekking spot for many people who want to experience the real taste of nature.

The hospitality locals of Tibetan group ""Tsombo"" truly amaze you. They welcome you with traditional Tibetan buttered, salted tea and local foods. This wonderful valley is likely to be your quest for the raw and absolute wilderness adventure for your lifetime.  ",,20181116,trip,http://trekkingtopnepal.com/trip/tsum-valley-trek/,http://trekkingtopnepal.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/14435745406_c7c8105666_b.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803986/himalayas_h8xjev.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803985/himalayas2_fhn0dq.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803985/himalayas3_k3vdfr.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803985/himalayas4_kapfgz.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803984/manali_dnd9xp.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803984/manali2_dfts5q.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803984/manali3_r4e5km.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803983/manali4_qzi3x6.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803983/manali5_cqro8g.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803983/manali6_ayp2s8.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803982/manali7_t2gobc.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803981/manali7jpg_qhpsa1.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803903/mountain_lve7qy.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803902/mountain2_lvzjst.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803902/mountaineerz_xwtali.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803902/Spiti-Valley-Marango-Rangarik-India_gbbjmj.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803901/sunrise_fybts6.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803901/trekking_vregae.jpg|https://res.cloudinary.com/trekkingtopnepal/image/upload/v1544803901/trekking2_hsqyka.jpg|http://trekkingtopnepal.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/2111943051_fb48c0d781_b.jpg|http://trekkingtopnepal.com/wp-content/u column3: Hide and seek views of Himalayan ranges such as Boudha Himal, Ganesh Himal and Shringi Himal throughout the trail.&lt
A spiritual visit to Rachen Gompa Monasteries and encounter with Tibetan culture and lifestyle.&lt
Less numbers of tourists makes this place truly exotic and interesting.&lt
Beautiful rhododendron forests, pine forests, coniferous forests, and high waterfalls through the trekking path.&lt

column1: Two clients share one porter. We will supply you a trek duffel bag where you keep your heavy items and this bag is carried by the porter. You will need to bring your own daypack to be carried by you. In the daypack, you can put money, important documents, water bottle/bladder, camera, toiletries, sunscreen, notebook, etc.

The weight limit for Kathmandu-Lukla-Kathmandu flights is 15 kg or 33 pounds. This is combining both the duffel bag and the daypack. If you exceed this limit, you will have to pay an additional fee. When this happens, sometimes the airline sends your bag in later flights and this can be very problematic for many reasons. So, we recommend you to pack as carefully as you can and not exceed the weight limit. You can leave your non-trekking stuff at the locker facility in the Kathmandu hotel.

column3: 4-season sleeping bag (We can provide one if you need it but has to be returned after the trek.)&lt
Down jacket (Must have for mornings, nights and evenings, and for altitudes above 4,000 m
column4: We can provide it if you need one but has to be returned after the trek.)&lt

column3: Wool or synthetic hat that cover the ears&lt
Soft shell and hard shell trekking pants&lt

column1: Please note our guide will carry the first-aid kit bag during the trek. However we still recommend you to bring your personalized first-aid kit as well.

column3: Extra Strength Excedrin for altitude related headaches&lt
Ibuprofen for general aches and pains&lt
Immodium or Pepto Bismol capsules for upset stomach or diarrhea&lt
Diamox (commonly prescribed as Acetazolamide) 125 or 250mg tablets for altitude sickness&lt

column5: Passport and extra passport photos (3 copies)&lt

column3: Airline ticket (Please make a copy and leave one at our office in Kathmandu just in case if you need to change the date of your flight.)&lt
Durable wallet/pouch for travel documents, money &amp
Toiletry kit (Be sure to include toilet paper stored in a plastic bag, hand wipes, and liquid hand sanitizer, towel, soap, etc.)&lt
Favorite snack foods (No more than 2 pounds)&lt
Cameras (Memory cards, chargers and also batteries)&lt
Pee bottle for men and pee funnel for women&lt
